arr.name: titledate_field
arr.str: Ms. Codex 1063 - [Book of hours : use of Sarum] (1450-1460)

marc:datafield.marc:subfield: 124 x 82 (95 x 60) mm. bound to 132 x 100 mm.

Book of hours produced in England, probably London, perhaps for a member of a religious confraternity or community. Includes calendar, Office of the Virgin (use of Sarum), Seven Penitential Psalms and incipits of the Gradual Psalms, litany, notated Office of the Dead (use of Sarum), and a variety of prayers. Evidence of use includes erasure of Thomas à Becket from calendar, erasures in text, and 17th-century additions to calendar.
2. f.7r-38r: Office of the Virgin, use of Sarum.
3. f.38r-47v: Seven Penitential Psalms and incipits of Gradual Psalms.
5. f.52v-89v: Office of the Dead, notated, use of Sarum.

Collation: Parchment, fol. i (modern paper) + ii (parchment) + 118 + i (parchment) + i (modern paper); 1⁶ 2-11⁸ 12³ (of 4, iv cancelled blank) 13⁸ 14⁵ (of 6?) 15-16⁸; horizontal catchwords in ink frames on last versos; older pagination (1-47 only) and collation notes in pencil, lower gutters; modern pencil foliation, lower right recto.
Layout: Written in 19 long lines; frame-ruled, in red ink to f. 63v and in black ink after; musical notation in the Office of the Dead in square neumes on a red four-line stave.
Script: Written in a formal Gothic script.

Decoration: Major text divisions open with illuminated foliate borders and 2- to 5-line initials (f. 7r, 13v, 23v, 26v, 28v, 30r, 32r, 33v, 38r, 52v), rubrics in red, 1- and 2-line initials alternately of burnished gold flourished blue and blue flourished red, line-fillers in the Litany of blue and gold.
Binding: 19th-century panelled brown morocco; all borders cropped for binding.
Origin: Written in England, probably London, between about 1450 and 1460.
Lawrence J. Schoenberg & Barbara Brizdle Manuscript Initiative.

Note in 16th-century hand identfying Thomas Appleby as a donor: Ex dono gratissimi viri M[agist]ri Thome Appulby socii Cantuberuii Whyttynton London (f. 117v); 17th-century note identifying Edmund Newman as a donor: Hic liber est ex dono p[at]ris Edm[und] Newman monachi cist[erciani] de Larha 1673 (f. 117v). Signature and note of medievalist William Maskell (f. i verso).
The Lawrence J. Schoenberg and Barbara Brizdle Manuscript Initiative Fund Home Page

recordinfo.str: 122 leaves : parchment ; 124 x 82 (95 x 60) mm. bound to 132 x 100 mm.

Book of hours produced in England, probably London, perhaps for a member of a religious confraternity or community. Includes calendar, Office of the Virgin (use of Sarum), Seven Penitential Psalms and incipits of the Gradual Psalms, litany, notated Office of the Dead (use of Sarum), and a variety of prayers. Evidence of use includes erasure of Thomas à Becket from calendar, erasures in text, and 17th-century additions to calendar.

Collation: Parchment, fol. i (modern paper) + ii (parchment) + 118 + i (parchment) + i (modern paper); 1⁶ 2-11⁸ 12³ (of 4, iv cancelled blank) 13⁸ 14⁵ (of 6?) 15-16⁸; horizontal catchwords in ink frames on last versos; older pagination (1-47 only) and collation notes in pencil, lower gutters; modern pencil foliation, lower right recto.
Layout: Written in 19 long lines; frame-ruled, in red ink to f. 63v and in black ink after; musical notation in the Office of the Dead in square neumes on a red four-line stave.
Script: Written in a formal Gothic script.

Decoration: Major text divisions open with illuminated foliate borders and 2- to 5-line initials (f. 7r, 13v, 23v, 26v, 28v, 30r, 32r, 33v, 38r, 52v), rubrics in red, 1- and 2-line initials alternately of burnished gold flourished blue and blue flourished red, line-fillers in the Litany of blue and gold.
Binding: 19th-century panelled brown morocco; all borders cropped for binding.
Origin: Written in England, probably London, between about 1450 and 1460.
Rare Book & Manuscript Library University of Pennsylvania Ms. Codex 1063
